{{distinguish|Counter-Enlightenment}}
The '''Dark Enlightenment''', or the '''neoreactionary movement'''—also known simply as '''neoreaction''' and abbreviated '''NRx''' by its proponents—is an [[Anti-democratic thought|anti-democratic]] and [[reactionary]] movement that considers itself to be the antithesis to the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]]. It broadly rejects [[egalitarianism]] and the view that history shows inevitable progression towards greater liberty and enlightenment, thus it is in part a reaction against "[[Whig history|Whig historiography]]".<ref name="TB">{{cite news|last=Pein|first=Corey|date=19 May 2014|title=Mouthbreathing Machiavellis Dream of a Silicon Reich|url=http://thebaffler.com/blog/mouthbreathing-machiavellis|newspaper=The Baffler|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209130630/http://thebaffler.com/blog/mouthbreathing-machiavellis|archivedate=9 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="TDT">{{cite news|last=Bartlett|first=Jamie|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/technology/jamiebartlett/100012093/meet-the-dark-enlightenment-sophisticated-neo-fascism-thats-spreading-fast-on-the-net/|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=Meet The Dark Enlightenment: sophisticated neo-fascism that's spreading fast on the net|date=20 January 2014}}</ref> The movement favors a return to older [[Social constructionism|societal constructs]] and forms of government, including support for [[monarchism]] and other forms of leadership such as a "neo[[Cameralism|cameralist]] CEO"<ref name=behind>{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/02/behind-the-internets-dark-anti-democracy-movement/516243/|title=Behind the Internet's Anti-Democracy Movement|date=10 February 2017|website=The Atlantic|last=Gray|first=Rosie}}</ref> of a [[Joint-stock company|joint-stock]] republic,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/448230/problems-mencius-moldbug-neoreaction|title=Against Mencius Moldbug's 'Neoreaction'|author=Steorts, Jason Lee|date=5 June 2017|publisher=National Review}}</ref> coupled with a [[Right-libertarianism|right-libertarian]], [[Conservatism|conservative]] or [[Economic nationalism|economic nationalist]] approach to economics.<ref name="AS">{{cite web|first=Matthew|last=Walther|url=http://spectator.org/blog/57516/dark-enlightenment-silly-not-scary|title=The Dark Enlightenment Is Silly Not Scary|website=[[The American Spectator]]|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=2 October 2014}}</ref> Proponents generally also espouse [[Social conservatism|socially conservative]] views on such matters as [[gender role]]s, [[Sociology of race and ethnic relations|race relations]] and [[Human migration|migration]].
A 2013 ''[[TechCrunch]]'' article describes "neoreactionaries" as a term applied to and sometimes a self-description of an informal "community of bloggers" and political theorists who have been active since the 2000s.<ref name="TechCrunch: Geeks for Monarchy">{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/11/22/geeks-for-monarchy/|website=TechCrunch|title=Geeks for Monarchy: The Rise of the Neoreactionaries|date=22 November 2013|first=Klint|last=Finley}}</ref> [[Steve Sailer]] and [[Hans-Hermann Hoppe]] are described as "contemporary forerunners" of the movement and neoreactionaries are also said to draw influence from philosophers such as [[Thomas Carlyle]] and [[Julius Evola]].<ref name="TechCrunch: Geeks for Monarchy"/> Writing in ''[[Taki's Magazine]]'', Nicholas James Pell notes that besides American computer scientist [[Curtis Yarvin]] and English author and philosopher [[Nick Land]], other prominent NRx voices include "monarchist [[Transhumanism|transhumanist]] Michael Anissimov, Catholic [[Anarchism|anarchist]] Bryce Laliberte, post-libertarian escape artist Jim, and the snarky satirists of ''Radish''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://takimag.com/article/overreacting_to_neoreaction_nicholas_james_pell|title=Overreacting to Neoreaction|author=Pell, Nicholas James|date=29 January 2014|work=Taki's Magazine}}</ref>
The Dark Enlightenment has been described as an early school of thought in the [[alt-right]].<ref name="qz">{{cite news|first1=Olivia|last1=Goldhill|accessdate=2018-05-27|title=The neo-fascist philosophy that underpins both the alt-right and Silicon Valley technophiles|url=https://qz.com/1007144/the-neo-fascist-philosophy-that-underpins-both-the-alt-right-and-silicon-valley-technophiles/|newspaper=Quartz}}</ref><ref name=warmed/> Some critics have also labeled the movement as "[[Neo-fascism|neo-fascist]]".<ref name="TDT"/><ref name=vocativ>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217072334/http://www.vocativ.com/12-2013/dark-enlightenment-creepy-internet-movement-youd-better-take-seriously/|url=http://www.vocativ.com/12-2013/dark-enlightenment-creepy-internet-movement-youd-better-take-seriously/|archivedate=17 December 2013|date=2 December 2013|first=Matt|last=Sigl|work=Vocativ|title=The Dark Enlightenment: The Creepy Internet Movement You’d Better Take Seriously}}</ref><ref name="qz" /> A 2016 ''New York Magazine'' piece notes: "Neoreaction has a number of different strains, but perhaps the most important is a form of post-libertarian [[futurism]] that, realizing that libertarians aren't likely to win any elections, argues against democracy in favor of [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] forms of government".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2016/06/peter-thiel.html|title=Why Peter Thiel Wants to Topple Gawker and Elect Donald Trump|author=MacDougald, Park|date=14 June 2016|work=New York Magazine}}</ref> Yarvin, for example, argues that a libertarian democracy is "simply an engineering contradiction, like a flying whale or a water-powered car".<ref name=terrifying/>
== Summary of core ideas <!--'Neocameralism' redirects here--> == [[File:Mencius Moldbug.jpg|thumb|[[Curtis Yarvin]], an early exponent of neoreactionary thought]] Some of the impetus for the neoreactionary movement comes from libertarians like [[Peter Thiel]] as indicated by [[Nick Land]]'s essay "The Dark Enlightenment", which noted how libertarian thinkers at an April 2009 ''[[Cato Unbound]]'' discussion expressed skepticism about the compatibility of freedom and democracy.<ref name="land-tde">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedarkenlightenment.com/the-dark-enlightenment-by-nick-land/|title=The Dark Enlightenment|author=Land, Nick}}</ref>
Yarvin's preferred system—named '''neocameralism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> after [[Frederick William I of Prussia]]'s system of [[Prussian cameralism]]<ref name="unhappy">{{cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/journal/81/125815/on-the-unhappy-consciousness-of-neoreactionaries/|title=On the Unhappy Consciousness of Neoreactionaries|author=Hui, Yuk|date=April 2017|publisher=e-flux}}</ref>—is a system in which a business owns the country,<ref name="behind"/> which is structured as a joint stock corporation divvied up into shares and run by a CEO to maximize profit.<ref name="bears">{{cite web|url=http://www.leapleapleap.com/2015/06/bears-will-never-steal-your-car-reacting-to-the-neoreactionaries/|title=Bears Will Never Steal Your Car|author=Goodman, Matthew Shen|date=9 June 2015|publisher=Leap}}</ref>
Peter Thiel and [[Patri Friedman]] have backed the [[Seasteading Institute]] as one possible way of building fiefdoms free of outside regulation and law.<ref name="TB"/>
Neoreactionary Michael Perilloux proposes that President [[Donald Trump]] seize more power by canceling the [[United States Constitution]], declaring [[martial law]] and replacing the government with [[The Trump Organization]].<ref name="warmed"/> Similarly, Google engineer [[Justine Tunney]] [[Justine Tunney#Petition to install a .22CEO of America.22|circulated a petition]] to appoint Google chairman [[Eric Schmidt]] as CEO of America.<ref name="TB" />
Some neoreactionary futurists focus more on the use of technology to defeat the state, for example, through transhumanist [[accelerationism]] in which the select few free themselves from the bonds of the state by evolving into superintelligent human-computer hybrids.<ref name="terrifying" /> One proponent of such ideas is Michael Anissimov, an advocate of [[eugenics]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The Specter of Eugenics: IQ, White Supremacy, and Human Enhancement|author=Abbott, Benjamin|date=5 June 2013|publisher=Ethical Technology|url=https://ieet.org/index.php/IEET2/more/abbott20130605}}</ref> who in the words of Mark O'Connell "has in recent years basically cornered the [[white supremacy|white-supremacy]]–[[technological singularity|singularity]] crossover market" and become "something of a pariah from the transhumanist movement". Rejecting the notion that all humans are created equal, Anissimov believes that there are already [[race and intelligence|disparities in intelligence between existing races]] and that transhuman technologies will create further disparities in power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2017/04/the-techno-libertarians-praying-for-dystopia.html|title=The Techno-Libertarians Praying for Dystopia|author=O'Connell, Mark|publisher=New York Magazine|date=30 April 2017}}</ref> He claims that aristocratic systems are more financially stable and less wasteful than democratic or communist systems.<ref name="TechCrunch: Geeks for Monarchy"/>
== History and etymology<!--'Formalism (Yarvin)' redirects here-->== Dylan Matthews argues that neoreaction draws on the racialist, traditionalist and isolationist arguments of [[paleoconservatism]] as well as paleoconservatives' belief that the mainstream is trying to crush them. Differences between the two movements are that paleoconservatives are more religious and have more faith in the United States Constitution and republican ideals generally.<ref name=warmed>{{cite web|title=The alt-right is more than warmed-over white supremacy. It’s that, but way way weirder.|publisher=Vox|author=Matthews, Dylan|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/4/18/11434098/alt-right-explained|date=25 August 2016}}</ref> Rick Searle draws parallels between neoreactionaries and late 19th century figures like [[Friedrich Nietzsche]], [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], [[Charles Maurras]] and [[Vilfredo Pareto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ieet.org/index.php/IEET2/more/Searle20160815|title=Shedding Light on Peter Thiel’s Dark Enlightenment|author=Searle, Rick|date=15 August 2016|publisher=Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies}}</ref> [[George Orwell]] also used the term "neo-reactionary" in an [[As I Please]] column for ''[[Tribune (magazine)|Tribune]]'' in 1943.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://telelib.com/authors/O/OrwellGeorge/essay/tribune/AsIPlease19431224.html|title=As I Please|work=Tribune|date=24 December 1943|first=George|last=Orwell}}</ref>
In 2007 and 2008, [[Curtis Yarvin]]—writing under the [[pen name]] Mencius Moldbug—articulated what would develop into Dark Enlightenment thinking. Yarvin's theories were later the subject of Nick Land, who first coined the term "Dark Enlightenment" in his essay of the same name.<ref name="land-tde" /> The term "Dark Enlightenment" is a play-on-words for the knowledge supposedly gained in the Enlightenment.<ref name="TDT"/><ref name="AS"/><ref name="TechCrunch: Geeks for Monarchy"/><ref name="SPLC">{{cite web |first=Jon|last=Phillips|url=https://secure.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2014/fall/Troublesome-Sources|title=Troublesome Sources|website=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=Fall 2014}}</ref> According to Land: "Where the progressive enlightenment sees political ideals, the dark enlightenment sees appetites"<ref name="land-tde"/>—on the view that the tendency of sovereign power (in democracies) is to devour society.
Yarvin had originally called his ideology '''formalism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> (a term inspired from [[legal formalism]]),<ref>{{Cite web|title = A formalist manifesto|url = http://unqualified-reservations.blogspot.com/2007/04/formalist-manifesto-originally-posted.html|website = Unqualified Reservations|accessdate = 21 June 2015|date = 23 April 2007|last = Moldbug|first = Mencius}}</ref> but [[Arnold Kling]] used the term "The Neo-Reactionaries" as a noun in July 2010 to describe Moldbug and fellows and the term was quickly adopted by the subculture.<ref name="TechCrunch: Geeks for Monarchy" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://econlog.econlib.org/archives/2010/07/the_neo-reactio.html|first=Arnold|last=Kling|authorlink=Arnold Kling|title=The Neo-Reactionaries|work=EconLog|publisher=Library of Economics and Liberty|date=18 July 2010|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> According to Adam Riggio, the embryo of the neoreactionary movement lived in the community pages of [[LessWrong]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://social-epistemology.com/2016/09/23/the-violence-of-pure-reason-neoreaction-a-basilisk-adam-riggio/|title=The Violence of Pure Reason|author=Riggio, Adam|publisher=Social Epistemology Review & Reply Collective|date=23 September 2016}}</ref> ''Social Matter'' is a major online publication and thought machine for neoreaction.<ref name=risealt>{{cite journal|title=The Rise of the Alt-Right Movement|author=Summers, Ryan T.|journal=Media and Communication Studies Summer Fellows|url=http://digitalcommons.ursinus.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1017&context=media_com_sum|date=2017|number=11| page=6 | quote=The ideology is also enthralled with hyper-masculine visions of men. In Post-Anathema, a Tumblr page, common images depict soldiers with guns, tanks, spacecraft, and Greek Gods.}}</ref>
Neoreactionaries have often declined reporters' requests for interviews, explaining that journalists—as [[Manufacturing Consent|manufacturers of consent]]—are their mortal enemy. When ''[[The Atlantic]]'' political affairs reporter [[Rosie Gray]] attempted to interview neoreactionary leaders, Yarvin suggested she instead "speak directly to my WH [[Cut-out (espionage)|cutout]] / [[Clandestine cell system|cell]] leader"—a sarcastic reference to widely reported yet unsubstantiated rumors that Yarvin had ties to [[White House Chief Strategist]] [[Steve Bannon]]—while Nick B. Steves told her she was ill-suited to write about neo-reaction because "115 IQ people are not generally well equipped to summarize 160 IQ people".<ref name=behind/>
Neoreactionary writings, particularly those by Yarvin<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/02/steve-bannon-books-reading-list-214745|title=What Steve Bannon Wants You to Read|author=Johnson, Eliana|publisher=Politico|date=7 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2015/06/17/the-right-stupid/co8uvp1VN8G6aSVZDCUbzN/story.html|title=The right to be stupid|author=Beam, Alex|date=18 June 2015|publisher=Boston Globe}}</ref> and Land, are sometimes viewed as so verbose, dense, discursive, detached and "edgy"<ref name=behind/> as to be inaccessible and self-marginalizing.<ref name=viewpoint>{{cite web|url=https://www.viewpointmag.com/2017/03/28/the-darkness-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel-artificial-intelligence-and-neoreaction/|title=The Darkness at the End of the Tunnel: Artificial Intelligence and Neoreaction|author=Haider, Shuja|date=28 March 2017|publisher=Viewpoint Magazine}}</ref><ref name=fueled>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/rosiegray/how-2015-fueled-the-rise-of-the-freewheeling-white-nationali|title=How 2015 Fueled The Rise Of The Freewheeling, White Nationalist Alt- Movement|author=Gray, Rosie|publisher=Buzzfeed|date=27 December 2015}}</ref>
Ryan Summers wrote that neoreactionary imagery is often infused with hyper-masculine ideas of men, such as tanks, spacecraft, Greek Gods and soldiers with guns.<ref name=risealt/>
== Relation to other movements == === Relation to the alt-right === Some consider the Dark Enlightenment as an early school of thought in the [[alt-right]],<ref name="qz" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/rosiegray/how-2015-fueled-the-rise-of-the-freewheeling-white-nationali|title=How 2015 Fueled The Rise Of The Freewheeling, White Nationalist Alt Right Movement|last=Gray|first=Rosie|date=28 December 2015|website=BuzzFeed|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-09}}</ref> or as its most theoretically minded branch.<ref name=warmed/> In particular, one philosopher with Landian ideas, [[Jason Reza Jorjani]], co-founded AltRight.com and spoke at the 2016 [[National Policy Institute]] conference led by white supremacist [[Richard B. Spencer|Richard Spencer]].<ref name=goldhill>{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/1007144/the-neo-fascist-philosophy-that-underpins-both-the-alt-right-and-silicon-valley-technophiles/|title=The neo-fascist philosophy that underpins both the alt-right and Silicon Valley technophiles|author=Goldhill, Olivia|date=18 June 2017|publisher=Quartz}}</ref> Some critics have also labeled the Dark Enlightenment as "[[Neo-fascism|neo-fascist]]"<ref name="TDT"/><ref name=vocativ>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217072334/http://www.vocativ.com/12-2013/dark-enlightenment-creepy-internet-movement-youd-better-take-seriously/|url=http://www.vocativ.com/12-2013/dark-enlightenment-creepy-internet-movement-youd-better-take-seriously/|archivedate=17 December 2013|date=2 December 2013|first=Matt|last=Sigl|work=Vocativ|title=The Dark Enlightenment: The Creepy Internet Movement You’d Better Take Seriously}}</ref> or as "an acceleration of capitalism to a fascist point", although Land argues this is inaccurate because fascism "is a mass [[Anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]] movement".<ref name=goldhill/> Land states:<ref name="behind" />{{quotation|NRx doesn't think the Alt-Right (in America) is very serious. It's an essentially Anti-Anglo-American philosophy, in its ([[Aleksandr Dugin|Duginist]]) core, which puts a firm ceiling on its potential. But then, the NRx analysis is that the age of the masses is virtually over. Riled-up populist movements are part of what is passing, rather than of what is slouching toward Bethlehem to be born.}} James Kirchick notes that although neoreactionary thinkers disdain the masses and claim to despise populism and people more generally, what ties them to the rest of the alt-right is their unapologetically racist element, their shared [[misanthropy]] and their resentment of mismanagement by the ruling elites.<ref name=terrifying>{{cite web|url=https://www.commentarymagazine.com/articles/trumps-terrifying-online-brigades/|title=Trump’s Terrifying Online Brigades|author=Kirchick, James|date=16 May 2016|publisher=Commentary Magazine}}</ref> Duesterberg observes: "As a rule the alt right is scattered, anonymous and obscure—thriving, as the curious metaphor has it, in the 'dark corners of the internet.' By contrast, neoreaction is centralized and public: darkness enlightened".<ref name=final>{{cite web|url=https://thepointmag.com/2017/politics/final-fantasy-neoreactionary-politics-liberal-imagination|title=Final Fantasy|author=Duesterberg, James|publisher=The Point|date=2017}}</ref>
== Criticism == A criticism of neoreaction is that its pessimistic appraisal of [[progressivism]]'s results dismisses many advances that have been made, including greater freedom for women, racial minorities and homosexuals; increased security for the elderly and unemployed; greater access to health care by the poor; steep declines in world [[poverty]];<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ieet.org/index.php/IEET2/more/brin20131130|author=Brin, David|publisher=Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies|date=30 November 2013|title="Neo-Reactionaries" drop all pretense: End democracy and bring back lords!}}</ref> improved [[air quality]]; greater [[religious tolerance]] and [[racial integration]]; lower [[crime rate]]s; and an absence of [[world war]]s since 1945. They also point to the culture of London, whose population is 40 percent nonwhite; and the high standard of living and continental peace in the [[European Union]]. Another criticism is that [[Economic globalization#Global supply chain|global manufacturing patterns]] limit the economic independence that sovereign states can have from one another.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sullivan, Andrew|date=30 April 2017|title=Why the reactionary right must be taken seriously|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/04/andrew-sullivan-why-the-reactionary-right-must-be-taken-seriously.html|publisher=New York Magazine}}</ref>
Some of the critics who felt the Dark Enlightenment's pessimistic assessment was unsupported by economic data formed the Grey Enlightenment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/19/eigenmorality-and-the-dark-enlightenment/|date=19 July 2014|publisher=TechCrunch|author=Evans, Jon|title=Eigenmorality And The Dark Enlightenment}}</ref>
Ryan T. Summers observes: "For the most part, neoreactionaries do not emphasize anti-Semitic views as other alt-right counterparts".<ref name="risealt" />
== See also == * [[Alt-lite]] * [[Aristocracy]] * [[Cultural conservatism]] * [[Enlightened absolutism]] * [[Fusionism]] * [[Manosphere]] * [[Natural order (philosophy)|Natural order]] * [[Neo-nationalism]] * [[Paleolibertarianism]] * [[Reactionary modernism]] * [[Social Darwinism]] * [[Speculative realism]] * [[Traditionalist conservatism]] * [[Traditionalist School]]

A '''deliberative referendum''' is a [[referendum]] that increases public deliberation through purposeful institutional design.<ref>Levy, Ron (2013) ″Deliberative Voting: Realising Constitutional Referendum Democracy″ Public Law p.557. </ref> The term ‵deliberative referendum′ stems from [[deliberative democracy]],<ref>Tierney, Stephen (2013) ″Using Electoral Law to Construct a Deliberative Referendum Moving Beyond the Democratic Paradox″12(4) Election Law Journal p.509. </ref> which emphasises that ″the legitimacy of decisions can be increased if ... decisions are preceded by authentic deliberation.″<ref>Leib, Ethan J (2006) ″Can Direct Democracy Be Made Deliberative?″ 54 Buffalo Law Review p.903.</ref> Deliberative design features can promote public deliberation prior to and during the referendum vote to increase its actual and perceived legitimacy.<ref name=Leib910>Leib, Ethan J (2006) ″Can Direct Democracy Be Made Deliberative?″ 54 Buffalo Law Review p.910.</ref> Deliberative referendums encourage open-minded and informed reasoning, rather than rigid ″pre-formed opinions.″<ref> Tierney, Stephen (2013) ″Using Electoral Law to Construct a Deliberative Referendum Moving Beyond the Democratic Paradox″ 12(4) Election Law Journal pp.508-512.</ref> ″[A]fter deliberations, citizens routinely alter their preferences″.<ref name=Leib910/>
In practice, a deliberative referendum includes a variety of institutional design features. These include using a [[citizens' jury]] to set referendum questions and educate the public, further public education via mandatory interactive tutorials before voting, and focusing referendums on broad values rather than technicalities.<ref>Levy, Ron (2017) ″The Deliberative Case for Constitutional Referenda ″ Election Journal p. 214-215. </ref> Some authors note how legal regulation can also aid referendum deliberation.<ref> Tierney, Stephen (2013) ″Using Electoral Law to Construct a Deliberative Referendum Moving Beyond the Democratic Paradox″ 12(4) Election Law Journal p.523.</ref>
One deliberative referendum method increasingly in use is the [[Citizens' Initiative Review]]; this is a randomly-selected body, similar to a citizen's jury, convened specifically to deliberate on a ballot [[initiative]] or [[referendum]] that voters in the same jurisdiction (such as a city, state, province, or country) will later vote on.<ref> John Gastil and Robert Richards, ‘Making Direct Democracy Deliberative Through Random Assemblies’ (2013) 41(2) , Politics & Society (2013) 41 (2).</ref>
[[Constitutional]] deliberative referendums can ″provide citizens with a meaningful say in determining the most fundamental constitutional decisions that affect their lives.″<ref> Tierney, Stephen (2013) ″Using Electoral Law to Construct a Deliberative Referendum Moving Beyond the Democratic Paradox″ 12(4) Election Law Journal p.510.</ref> Voter deliberation is significant here as the referendum result could change the state’s political status or impact the enjoyment of human rights.<ref>Levy, Ron (2013) ″Deliberative Voting: Realising Constitutional Referendum Democracy″ Public Law p.559.</ref>

{{wiktionary|demokratia}} {{Forms of government}} '''Demokratia''' ({{lang-el|δημοκρατία}}) is a [[direct democracy]], as opposed to the modern [[representative democracy]]. It was used in ancient [[Greece]], most notably [[Athens]], and began its use around 500 BCE. In a participant government, citizens who wish to have a say in government can participate in it. Demokratia excluded women, foreigners, and slaves. It barred between 80 and 90 percent of the population from political rights.Morris & Raaflaub ''Democracy 2500?: Questions and Challenges'' The word demokratia comes from δῆμος ''demos'' "people" and ''kratos'' "power": "the people hold power." ''Demos'', including the lower classes, had political equality and notwhile respecting laws and institutions, was given full and absolute control of power and government."Morris & Raaflaub ''Democracy 2500?: Questions and Challenges''p.34 In some languages, including Finnish, Demokratia is a word simply meaning democracy. Quoted from [https://web.archive.org/web/20070808234819/http://car.owu.edu/Vol.%2018%20No.%201.htm MODERN AMERICA AND THE RELIGION OF DEMOCRACY (Internet archive)] by Loren J Samons II:
In classical Athens, religion suffused every aspect of public life, from the theater to the military to the political assembly. The state (that is, the citizens) sponsored religious festivals and actively participated in the propitiation and worship of the gods. This fact well illustrates the way the various aspects of Athenian society — religious, political, economic, and social — overlapped with and affected one another, and the way every Athenian found himself set firmly within a matrix of duties to the gods, to his family, and to his fellow citizens. The principle of necessary duties (especially to protect the family, to serve the polis, and to propitiate the gods) formed the basic structure of Athenian society, and gave meaning to each religious, economic, military, and political act. In such an environment, it was impossible for the Athenians abjectly to worship a form of government, demokratia, even after they had made it a goddess. The idea that the "freedom to make choices" or "diversity" were absolute goods and thus could serve as goals or ideals (on a level with, much less above, family, gods, or polis) contradicted the very premises of Athenian society. Thus while democratic practices ultimately had a marked and deleterious effect on Athenian national strength and public morale and arguably contributed to the loss of Athenian independence, Athenian society managed to stave off the most harmful aspects of democratic theory. Even after they lost their democracy and autonomy, there is little evidence that the Athenians completely lost their fundamental conception of a society based on the principle of duties.
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==Literature== I. Morris & K. Raaflaub (ed.), ''Democracy 2500?: Questions and Challenges'', Kendal/Hunt Publishing Co., 1998 ==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070808234819/http://car.owu.edu/Vol.%2018%20No.%201.htm MODERN AMERICA AND THE RELIGION OF DEMOCRACY (Internet archive)] by Loren J Samons II Department of Classical Studies, Boston University. (Excerpted from What’s Wrong With Democracy? Published by the University of California Press). [[Category:Direct democracy]] [[Category:Types of democracy]] {{politics-stub}}

{{About|the theory involving communist countries|the Weather Report album|Domino Theory (album)|the Steve Wariner song|The Domino Theory}} [[File:Domino theory.svg|thumb|350px|An illustration of the domino theory as it had been predicted]]
The '''domino theory''' was a theory prominent from the 1950s to the 1980s that posited that if one country in a region came under the influence of [[communism]], then the surrounding countries would follow in a '''[[domino effect]]'''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leeson|first1=Peter T.|last2=Dean|first2=Andrea|title=The Democratic Domino Theory|journal=American Journal of Political Science|date=2009|volume=53|issue=3|pages=533–551|doi=10.1111/j.1540-5907.2009.00385.x}}</ref> The domino theory was used by successive United States administrations during the [[Cold War]] to justify the need for [[Overseas interventions of the United States|American intervention]] around the world.
[[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] described the theory during an April 7, 1954, news conference, when referring to communism in [[Indochina]]:
{{quote|Finally, you have broader considerations that might follow what you would call the "falling domino" principle. You have a row of dominoes set up, you knock over the first one, and what will happen to the last one is the certainty that it will go over very quickly. So you could have a beginning of a disintegration that would have the most profound influences.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.nps.gov/features/eise/jrranger/quotes2.htm | title =The Quotable Quotes of Dwight D. Eisenhower | publisher =[[National Park Service]] | date =December 5, 2013 | access-date =2013-12-05 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130328071311/http://www.nps.gov/features/eise/jrranger/quotes2.htm# | archive-date =2013-03-28 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref>}}
==History== In 1945, the [[Soviet Union]] brought most of the countries of eastern Europe and Central Europe into its influence as part of the post-World War II new settlement,<ref>{{cite web | url =http://iis-db.stanford.edu/evnts/6186/Stalin_and_Eastern_Europe.pdf | title =STALIN, SOVIET POLICY, AND THE CONSOLIDATION OF A COMMUNIST BLOC IN EASTERN EUROPE, 1944-1953 | author =Mark Kramer | publisher =[[Stanford University]] | date =April 30, 2010 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131021040535/http://iis-db.stanford.edu/evnts/6186/Stalin_and_Eastern_Europe.pdf | archivedate =October 21, 2013 | df = }}</ref> prompting [[Winston Churchill]] to declare in a speech in 1946 at [[Westminster College (Missouri)|Westminster College]] in [[Fulton, Missouri]] that:
{{quote|From [[Szczecin|Stettin]] in the [[Baltic sea|Baltic]] to [[Trieste]] in the [[Adriatic Sea|Adriatic]] an "[[Iron Curtain]]" has descended across the Continent. Behind that line lie all the capitals of the ancient states of Central and Eastern Europe. [[Warsaw]], [[Prague]], [[Budapest]], [[Belgrade]], [[Bucharest]] and [[Sofia]]; all these famous cities and the populations around them lie in what I must call the Soviet sphere, and all are subject, in one form or another, not only to Soviet influence but to a very high and in some cases increasing measure of control from Moscow.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.winstonchurchill.org/resources/speeches/1946-1963-elder-statesman/120-the-sinews-of-peace | title =The Iron Curtain: Winston S. Churchill, "The Sinews of Peace," speech, 1946 | publisher =[[The International Churchill Society]] | year =2017 | access-date =2017-01-09 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170128181818/http://www.winstonchurchill.org/resources/speeches/1946-1963-elder-statesman/120-the-sinews-of-peace# | archive-date =2017-01-28 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref>}}
Following the [[Iran crisis of 1946]], [[Harry S. Truman]] declared what became known as the [[Truman Doctrine]] in 1947,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQquNKw1tZwC&pg=PA373&lpg=PA373&dq=after+the+Iran+crisis+of+1946,+Harry+Truman+declared+the+trumandoctrine&source=bl&ots=8gQBazTtnF&sig=Cq1QwGx0WtEB9OzdIBaQ2CFwgrI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3TegUtDaNOamygHKh4HABg&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=after%20the%20Iran%20crisis%20of%201946%2C%20Harry%20Truman%20declared%20the%20trumandoctrine&f=false | title =A Companion to Harry S. Truman | author =Daniel S. Margolies | isbn =978-1444331417 | pages =372, 373 | publisher =books.Google.com | year =2012}}</ref> promising to contribute financial aid to Greece during their [[Greek Civil War|Civil War]] and to [[Turkey]] following World War II, in the hope that this would impede the advancement of Communism into Western Europe.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/truman-doctrine | title =The Truman Doctrine, 1947 | publisher =[[United States Department of State]] [[Office of the Historian]], [[Bureau of Public Affairs]] | date =December 5, 2013 | access-date =2017-06-14 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170516181411/https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/truman-doctrine# | archive-date =2017-05-16 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> Later that year, diplomat [[George F. Kennan|George Kennan]] wrote an article in ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' magazine that became known as the "[[X Article]]", which first articulated the policy of [[containment]],<ref>{{cite web | url =https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/kennan | title =Kennan and Containment, 1947 | publisher =[[United States Department of State]] [[Office of the Historian]], [[Bureau of Public Affairs]] | date =December 5, 2013 | access-date =2017-06-14 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170628012824/https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/kennan# | archive-date =2017-06-28 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> arguing that the further spread of Communism to countries outside a "[[buffer zone]]" around the USSR, even if it happened via democratic elections, was unacceptable and a threat to U.S. national security.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/23331/x/the-sources-of-soviet-conduct | title=The Sources of Soviet Conduct | author=[[George F. Kennan|Kennan, George]] | work=[[Foreign Affairs]] | date=July 1947 | access-date=2013-12-05 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212043538/http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/23331/x/the-sources-of-soviet-conduct# | archive-date=2013-12-12 | dead-url=no | df= }}</ref> Kennan was also involved, along with others in the [[Harry S. Truman#Presidency|Truman administration]], in creating the [[Marshall Plan]],<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CWll1goeBzwC&pg=PA1944&lpg=PA1944&dq=George+Kennan+involved+in+drafting+marshall+plan&source=bl&ots=TLu5J5wZM_&sig=Kh-bJYqCS7ni-wg6NDeoel8yXRs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MEKgUoi7EqacyQGZ5oCYAQ&ved=0CGUQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=George%20Kennan%20involved%20in%20drafting%20marshall%20plan&f=false | title =George Kennan: A Study of Character | author =John Lukacs | publisher=Yale University Press | isbn =978-0300143065 | year =2009}}</ref> which also began in 1947, to give aid to the countries of Western Europe (along with Greece and Turkey),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dergiler.ankara.edu.tr/dergiler/44/1569/17035.pdf | title =TURKEY AND THE MARSHALL PLAN: STRIVE FOR AID | author =Senem Üstün | author2 =The Turkish Yearbook of International Relations | publisher =[[Ankara University]] | volume =27 | issue =0 | pages =31–52 | year =1997}}</ref> in large part with the hope of keeping them from falling under Soviet domination.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/short-history/truman | title =The Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan | publisher =[[United States Department of State]] [[Office of the Historian]], [[Bureau of Public Affairs]] | date =December 5, 2013 | access-date =2017-06-14 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170512021347/https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/short-history/truman# | archive-date =2017-05-12 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref>
In 1949, a Communist-backed government, led by [[Mao Zedong]], was instated in China (officially becoming the [[China|People's Republic of China]]).<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/mao-zedong-outlines-the-new-chinese-government | title =Mao Zedong outlines the new Chinese government | publisher =[[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] | date =December 5, 2013 | access-date =2013-12-05 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20131102093822/http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/mao-zedong-outlines-the-new-chinese-government# | archive-date =2013-11-02 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> The installation of the new government was established after the [[People's Liberation Army]] defeated the [[Nationalist government|Nationalist Republican Government of China]] in the aftermath of the [[Chinese Civil War]] (1927-1949).<ref name="ChineseRev">{{cite web | url =https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/chinese-rev | title =The Chinese Revolution of 1949 | publisher =[[United States Department of State]] [[Office of the Historian]], [[Bureau of Public Affairs]] | access-date =2017-06-14 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170519004017/https://history.state.gov/milestones/1945-1952/chinese-rev# | archive-date =2017-05-19 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> Two Chinas were formed - mainland 'Communist China' (People's Republic of China) and 'Nationalist China' Taiwan ([[Taiwan|Republic of China]]). The takeover by Communists of the world's most populous nation was seen in the West as a great strategic loss, prompting the popular question at the time, "Who lost China?"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=n3oay_KTHwoC&pg=PA230&lpg=PA230&source=web&ots=zJEMhUw3FQ&sig=Hv-UEoi7Otexk7nArwaotvulO9E&hl=en#PPA230,M1 Rogue Regimes: Terrorism and Proliferation, pg. 230], Raymond Tanter, Macmillan, 1999</ref> The United States subsequently ended diplomatic relations with China in response to the communist takeover in 1949.<ref name ="ChineseRev"/>
[[Korea]] had also partially fallen under Soviet domination at the end of World War II, split from the south of the [[38th parallel north|38th parallel]] where U.S. forces subsequently moved into. By 1948, as a result of the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the U.S., Korea was split into two regions, with separate governments, each claiming to be the legitimate government of Korea, and neither side accepting the border as permanent. In 1950 fighting broke out between Communists and Republicans that soon involved troops from China (on the Communists' side), and the United States and 15 allied countries (on the Republicans' side). Though the [[Korean War|war]] never officially ended, the fighting ended in 1953 with an [[Korean Armistice Agreement|armistice]] that left Korea divided into two nations, [[North Korea]] and [[South Korea]]. Mao Zedong's decision to take on the U.S. in the Korean War was a direct attempt to confront what the Communist bloc viewed as the strongest anti-Communist power in the world, undertaken at a time when the Chinese Communist regime was still consolidating its own power after winning the Chinese Civil War.
President Eisenhower was the first to refer to countries in danger of Communist takeover as dominoes, in response to a journalist's question about Indochina in an April 7, 1954 news conference, though he did not use the term "domino theory".<ref>Dwight D. Eisenhower: "[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=10202 The President's News Conference] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201033903/http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=10202# |date=2017-12-01 }}," April 7, 1954. Online by Gerhard Peters and John T. Woolley, ''The Presidency Project.'' Retrieved 28 Nov. 2017.</ref> If Communists succeeded in taking over the rest of Indochina, Eisenhower argued, local groups would then have the encouragement, material support and momentum to take over [[Post-independence Burma, 1948–62|Burma]], [[Thailand]], [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] and [[Indonesia]]; all of these countries had large popular Communist movements and insurgencies within their borders at the time.
In May 1954, the [[Viet Minh]], a Communist and nationalist army, defeated French troops in the [[Battle of Dien Bien Phu]] and took control of what became [[North Vietnam]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/asiapacific-region/french-indochinavietnam-1941-1954/ | title =11. French Indochina/Vietnam (1941-1954) | author =''[[University of Central Arkansas]]'' | publisher =uca.edu | access-date =2013-12-05 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140517074321/http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/asiapacific-region/french-indochinavietnam-1941-1954# | archive-date =2014-05-17 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> This caused the French to fully withdraw from the region then known as [[French Indochina]], a process they had begun earlier.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://novaonline.nvcc.edu/eli/evans/his135/events/dienbienphu54.htm | title =1954 DIEN BIEN PHU | publisher =[[Northern Virginia Community College]] | access-date =2013-12-05 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130601141617/http://novaonline.nvcc.edu/eli/evans/his135/events/dienbienphu54.htm# | archive-date =2013-06-01 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref> The regions were then divided into four independent countries (North Vietnam, [[South Vietnam]], [[Kingdom of Cambodia (1953–70)|Cambodia]] and [[Kingdom of Laos|Laos]]) after a deal was brokered at the [[Geneva Conference (1954)|1954 Geneva Conference]] to end the [[First Indochina War]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/21/newsid_3894000/3894175.stm | title =1954: Peace deal ends Indo-China war | publisher =[[BBC]] | date =July 21, 1954 | access-date =2013-12-05 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130120185805/http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/21/newsid_3894000/3894175.stm# | archive-date =2013-01-20 | dead-url =no | df = }}</ref>
This would give them a geographical and economic strategic advantage, and it would make Japan, [[Taiwan]], the [[Philippines]], Australia, and New Zealand the front-line defensive states. The loss of regions traditionally within the vital regional trading area of countries like Japan would encourage the front-line countries to compromise politically with communism.
Eisenhower's domino theory of 1954 was a specific description of the situation and conditions within [[Southeast Asia]] at the time, and he did not suggest a generalized domino theory as others did afterward.
The [[John F. Kennedy]] administration intervened in Vietnam in the early 1960s to, among other reasons, keep the South Vietnamese "domino" from falling. When Kennedy came to power there was concern that the communist-led [[Pathet Lao]] in Laos would provide the [[Viet Cong]] with bases, and that eventually they could take over Laos.
==Arguments in favor of the domino theory== {{refimprove|section|date=April 2018}} The primary evidence for the domino theory is the spread of communist rule in three Southeast Asian countries in 1975, following the [[Vietnam War|communist takeover of Vietnam]]: South Vietnam (by the Viet Cong), Laos (by the Pathet Lao), and Cambodia (by the [[Khmer Rouge]]). It can further be argued that before they finished taking Vietnam prior to the 1950s, the communist campaigns did not succeed in Southeast Asia. Note the [[Malayan Emergency]], the [[Hukbalahap Rebellion]] in the [[Philippines]], and the increasing involvement with [[Communist Party of Indonesia|Communists]] by [[Sukarno]] of Indonesia from the late 1950s until he was deposed in 1967. All of these were unsuccessful Communist attempts to take over Southeast Asian countries which stalled when communist forces were still focused in Vietnam.
[[Walt Whitman Rostow]] and the then [[Prime Minister of Singapore]] [[Lee Kuan Yew]] have argued that the U.S. intervention in Indochina, by giving the nations of [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] time to consolidate and engage in economic growth, prevented a wider domino effect.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lee |first=Kuan Yew |date=2000 |title=From Third World to First: The Singapore Story - 1965-2000 |location=New York |publisher=Harper Collins |page=467,573 |isbn=0-06-019776-5 }}</ref> Meeting with President [[Gerald Ford]] and [[Henry Kissinger]] in 1975, Lee Kuan Yew argued that "there is a tendency in the U.S. Congress not to want to export jobs. But we have to have the jobs if we are to stop Communism. We have done that, moving from simple to more complex skilled labor. If we stop this process, it will do more harm than you can every[sic] repair with aid. Don't cut off imports from Southeast Asia."<ref>[[:File:Ford, Kissinger, Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew - May 8, 1975(Gerald Ford Library)(1553067).pdf|Ford, Kissinger, Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew - May 8, 1975 (Gerald Ford Library)]], pg. 7</ref>
[[McGeorge Bundy]] argued that the prospects for a domino effect, though high in the 1950s and early 1960s, were weakened in 1965 when the [[Indonesian killings of 1965–66|Indonesian Communist Party was destroyed]] via CIA-supported death squads in the Indonesian genocide. However, proponents believe that the efforts during the containment (i.e. Domino Theory) period ultimately led to the demise of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War.
Some supporters of the domino theory note the history of communist governments supplying aid to communist revolutionaries in neighboring countries. For instance, China supplied the [[Viet Minh]], the North Vietnamese army, with troops and supplies, and the Soviet Union supplied them with tanks and heavy weapons. The fact that the Pathet Lao and Khmer Rouge were both originally part of the Vietminh, not to mention Hanoi's support for both in conjunction with the Viet Cong, also give credence to the theory. The Soviet Union also heavily supplied Sukarno with military supplies and advisors from the time of the [[Guided Democracy in Indonesia]], especially during and after the 1958 civil war in Sumatra.
Linguist and political theorist [[Noam Chomsky]] wrote that he believes that the domino theory is roughly accurate, although he put a more positive spin on the threat, writing that communist and socialist movements became popular in poorer countries because they brought economic improvements to those countries in which they took power. For this reason, he wrote, the U.S. put so much effort into suppressing so-called "people's movements" in [[Chile]], Vietnam, [[Nicaragua]], Laos, [[Grenada]], [[El Salvador]], [[Guatemala]], etc. "The weaker and poorer a country is, the more dangerous it is as an example. If a tiny, poor country like Grenada can succeed in bringing about a better life for its people, some other place that has more resources will ask, 'Why not us?'" Chomsky refers to this as the "threat of a good example".<ref>[http://www.chomsky.info/books/unclesam01.htm "The Threat of a Good Example"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724125605/http://www.chomsky.info/books/unclesam01.htm# |date=2015-07-24 }}, [[Noam Chomsky]]</ref>
==Applications to communism outside Southeast Asia== [[Michael Lind]] has argued that though the domino theory failed regionally, there was a global wave, as communist or [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] regimes came to power in [[People's Republic of Benin|Benin]], [[Derg|Ethiopia]], [[Guinea-Bissau]], [[Democratic Republic of Madagascar|Madagascar]], [[Cape Verde]], [[People's Republic of Mozambique|Mozambique]], [[Angola]], [[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]], [[People's Revolutionary Government (Grenada)|Grenada]], and [[Nicaragua]] during the 1970s. The global interpretation of the domino effect relies heavily upon the "prestige" interpretation of the theory, meaning that the success of Communist revolutions in some countries, though it did not provide material support to revolutionary forces in other countries, did contribute morale and rhetorical support.
In this vein, Argentine revolutionary [[Che Guevara]] wrote an essay, the "Message to the Tricontinental", in 1967, calling for "two, three ... many Vietnams" across the world.<ref>[http://www.mindfully.org/Reform/2005/Che-Guevara-Gott11aug05.htm "Rough Draft of History: 'All Right, Let's Get the @#!*% Out of Here'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051126071737/http://www.mindfully.org/Reform/2005/Che-Guevara-Gott11aug05.htm |date=2005-11-26 }}, Richard Gott, August 11, 2005</ref> Historian [[Max Boot]] wrote, "In the late 1970s, America's enemies seized power in countries from Mozambique to Iran to Nicaragua. American hostages were seized aboard the SS ''Mayaguez'' (off Cambodia) and in Tehran. The [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet Army invaded Afghanistan]]. There is no obvious connection with the Vietnam War, but there is little doubt that the defeat of a superpower encouraged our enemies to undertake acts of aggression that they might otherwise have shied away from."<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118792232818807567 "Another Vietnam?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709153053/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118792232818807567# |date=2017-07-09 }}, Max Boot, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', August 24, 2007</ref>
In addition, this theory can be further bolstered by the rise in terrorist incidents by left-wing terrorist groups in Western Europe, funded in part by Communist governments, between the 1960s and 1980s.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/world/russia/kgb/su0523.htm# |title=KGB Active Measures |access-date=2015-06-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629193045/https://fas.org/irp/world/russia/kgb/su0523.htm# |archive-date=2015-06-29 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/world/para/raf.htm# |title=Red Army Faction |access-date=2015-06-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629203451/https://fas.org/irp/world/para/raf.htm# |archive-date=2015-06-29 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://fas.org/irp/world/para/br.htm# |title=Brigate Rosse |access-date=2015-06-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150629232055/https://fas.org/irp/world/para/br.htm# |archive-date=2015-06-29 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> In Italy, this includes the kidnapping and assassination of former Italian Prime Minister [[Aldo Moro]], and the kidnapping of former US Brigadier General [[James L. Dozier]], by the [[Red Brigades]].
In West Germany, this includes the terrorist actions of the [[Red Army Faction]]. In the far east the [[Japanese Red Army]] carried out similar acts. All four, as well as others worked with various Arab and Palestinian terrorists, which like the red brigades were backed by the Soviet Bloc.
In the 1977 [[The Nixon Interviews|Frost/Nixon interviews]], [[Richard Nixon]] defended America's destabilization of the [[Salvador Allende]] regime in Chile on domino theory grounds. Borrowing a metaphor he had heard, he stated that a Communist Chile and [[Cuba]] would create a "red sandwich" that could entrap Latin America between them.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=5mUrNoWa7J0C&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=Chile%2Bcuba%2Bred+sandwich&source=web&ots=495XIVdXHA&sig=-Cxk0QCxL6Ab82RqdR_fJINZ2mg&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=2&ct=result The Last Years of the Monroe Doctrine, 1945-1993, p. 133] Gaddis Smith</ref> In the 1980s, the domino theory was used again to justify the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]]'s interventions in Central America and the [[Invasion of Grenada|Caribbean region]].
In his memoirs, former [[Prime Minister of Rhodesia|Rhodesian Prime Minister]] [[Ian Smith]] described the successive rise of authoritarian left-wing governments in Sub-Saharan Africa during [[Decolonisation of Africa|decolonization]] as "the communists' domino tactic".<ref>{{cite book |title=[[The Great Betrayal: The Memoirs of Ian Douglas Smith|Bitter Harvest: Zimbabwe and the Aftermath of Its Independence]] |last=Smith |first=Ian |authorlink=Ian Smith |year=2008 |publisher=[[John Blake Publishing]] |location=London |isbn=978-1-84358-548-0 |page=280 |pages=}}</ref> The establishment of pro-communist governments in [[Tanzania]] (1961–64) and [[Zambia]] (1964) and explicitly Marxist–Leninist governments in Angola (1975), Mozambique (1975), and eventually [[Rhodesia]] itself (in 1980)<ref>Smith 2008: 147</ref> are cited by Smith as evidence of "the insidious encroachment of Soviet imperialism down the continent".<ref>Smith 2008: 183</ref>
==Other applications== [[File:Hosni Mubarak facing the Tunisia domino effect.png|thumb|Political cartoon by [[Carlos Latuff]] applying the domino theory to the [[Arab Spring]].|alt=The cartoon depicts Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak as the next to fall after the Tunisian revolution forced President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali to flee the country.]]
Some foreign policy analysts in the United States have referred to the potential spread of both Islamic theocracy and liberal democracy in the Middle East as two different possibilities for a domino theory. During the [[Iran–Iraq War]] the United States and other western nations supported [[Ba'athist Iraq]], fearing the spread of Iran's radical theocracy throughout the region. In the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], some [[Neoconservatism|neoconservative]]s argued that when a democratic government is implemented, it would then help spread democracy and [[liberalism]] across the Middle East. This has been referred to as a "reverse domino theory,"<ref>[http://www.slate.com/id/2080976/nav/navoa/ "The War and the Peace"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624135941/http://www.slate.com/id/2080976/nav/navoa/# |date=2007-06-24 }}, Robert Wright, ''Slate'', April 1, 2003</ref> or a "democratic domino theory,"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reynolds|first1=Paul|title=The 'democratic domino' theory|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2935969.stm|agency=BBC News|date=April 10, 2003|access-date=2016-09-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003074026/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2935969.stm#|archive-date=2016-10-03|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> so called because its effects are considered positive, not negative, by Western democratic states.

The '''East StratCom Task Force''' is a part of the [[Public administration|administration]] of the [[European union|European Union]], focused on [[proactive]] communication of EU [[policy|policies]] and activities in the Eastern neighbourhood ([[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Belarus]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Moldova]] and [[Ukraine]])<ref name="theg">{{cite web|title=EU to counter Russian propaganda by promoting 'European values'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/25/eu-russia-propaganda-ukraine|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=28 November 2015|date=25 June 2015}}</ref> and beyond<ref name="ap">{{cite web|author1=East StratCom Team|title=Action Plan on Strategic Communication|website=[[Eastern Partnership]] Civil Society Forum|accessdate=28 November 2015|ref=Ref. Ares(2015)2608242 - 22/06/2015|pages=5| url=http://eap-csf.eu/assets/files/Action%20PLan.pdf |format=pdf}}</ref> ([[Russia]] itself).<ref name="theg" /> The Team was created as a conclusion of the [[European Council]] meeting on 19 and 20 March 2015, stressing the need to challenge the ongoing [[disinformation]] campaigns by [[Russia]].“<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eesc.europa.eu/resources/docs/european-council-conclusions-19-20-march-2015-en.pdf|title=European Council meeting (19 and 20 March 2015) - Conclusions|first=|date=2015-03-20|website=|location=Brussels|at=Paragraph 13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|author1=European Council|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref>
== Mission and objectives == The East Stratcom Team is intended to develop dedicated communication material on priority issues, where EU [[strategic communication]] needs to be improved or the EU is subject to [[disinformation]] campaigns. Such products will be put at the disposal of the EU's political leadership, press services, EU [[delegation]]s and EU Member States and are intended for the widest possible public audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-Homepage/2116/questions-and-answers-about-east-stratcom-task-force_en|title=Questions and Answers about the East StratCom Task Force - EEAS - European External Action Service - European Commission|website=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> The Team is designated to develop communication campaigns, targeting key [[audience]]s and focused on specific issues of relevance to those audiences, including local issues. The actions of the East Stratcom Team are built on existing work and coherent with wider EU communication efforts, including activities of the EU institutions and EU Member States.<ref name="ap" />
== Key Task Force products == The team's positive communications products are mainly focused on the countries of the Eastern Neighbourhood and produced in the local languages of those countries. They are distributed via social media channels of the EU Delegations in the region, and are also carried on television and via other media and public events.<ref name="Q & A">{{cite web|title=Questions and Answers about the East StratCom Task Force|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-Homepage/2116/questions-and-answers-about-east-stratcom-task-force_en|publisher=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en}} Material has been copied from this source. Reuse is authorised, provided the source is acknowledged.</ref> In addition, the Task Force, in cooperation with the European Commission, led the EU's six month Eastern Partnership communications campaign culminating in the November 2017 Eastern Partnership Summit in Brussels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage/36233/eastern-partnership-summit-24112017_en|title=Eastern Partnership summit, 24/11/2017 - EEAS - European External Action Service - European Commission|website=EEAS - European External Action Service|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>
The team's main product to raise awareness of disinformation is the weekly Disinformation Review (in English and Russian languages). This can provide valuable data for analysts, journalists and officials dealing with this issue. The Disinformation Review also brings the latest news and analyses of pro-Kremlin disinformation.<ref name="Q & A"/> Launched in November 2015, the Disinformation Review has been described as "the best weekly disinformation bulletin anywhere in the West"<ref>{{Citation|last=|title=Lecture by Edward Lucas|date=2016-07-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sx_cqNR3bJA%7Clanguage=en%7Caccessdate=2018-03-19|accessdate=2018-04-04}}</ref>. The full record of the Task Force's work on disinformation is available on its website [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ EUvsDisinfo.eu] (in [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/news/ English], [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/ru/ Russian] and [https://euvsdisinfo.eu/de/ German] languages). The team also runs the European External Action Service's [https://eeas.europa.eu/ru/eu-information-russian_ru Russian language website]. It is also possible to follow the team on Twitter and Facebook. This communicates primarily about the EU's foreign policy by publishing information about EU activities, as well as EU statements and press releases with relevance to the Eastern Neighbourhood in particular.<ref name="Q & A"/>
== Reception and criticism == EU Member State Governments have strongly supported the Task Force since its inception and provide the majority of its staff.
The European Parliament has consistently supported the Task Force and called for adequate staffing and resourcing. An EP preparatory action for 2018 – "StratCom Plus" - has allocated €1.1m for the team to focus on how to counter disinformation on the EU more systematically.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/25/eu-anti-propaganda-unit-gets-1m-a-year-to-counter-russian-fake-news|title=EU anti-propaganda unit gets €1m a year to counter Russian fake news|last=Rankin|first=Jennifer|date=2017-11-25|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * [[Pavel Telička|Pavel Telicka]], Vice-President of the European Parliament: "I place great value in the fact that Europe has experts who address Russia's ongoing disinformation campaigns (…). The quality and the substance of their work is outstanding. Their work is valuable as it indicated the alarming nature of our European security".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telicka.eu/cs/articles/detail/647|title=Pavel Telička píše F. Mogheriniové. Oceňuje práci East StratCom Task Force|last=<hello@unchained.studio|first=UNCHAINED.studio|website=www.telicka.eu|language=cs|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * Keir Giles from [[Chatham House]] about East StratCom Task Force: "a critically important capability, ESTF has quite a high credit among experts".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transparency/regexpert/index.cfm?do=groupDetail.groupDetail&groupID=3567&news=1|title=Register of Commission expert groups and other similar entities|website=ec.europa.eu|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * European Security Union Commissioner [[Julian King (diplomat)|Julian King]] noted that East Stratcom Task Force "gathered more than 3,500 examples of pro-Kremlin disinformation contradicting publicly available facts repeated on many languages on many occasions”;<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.neweurope.eu/article/meps-call-boosting-eu-resilience-russian-propaganda/|title=MEPs call for boosting EU resilience to Russian propaganda|date=2018-01-18|work=New Europe|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US}}</ref> "It also launched a Russian language service from Brussels, providing updates and fact-based background information about the Union for RU language journalists. The aim is to increase visibility and more accurate representation of EU policies in the Russian language media. It produces a weekly Disinformation review. Their Twitter account ensures that the Task Force's products reach up to 2 million people per month, in addition to their regular briefings. This work is very important".<ref name="europarl.europa.eu">{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/ep-live/en/plenary/video?debate=1516197858767|title=Plenary video: Russia - the influence of propaganda on EU countries {{!}} Multimedia centre {{!}} European Parliament|website=Multimedia centre {{!}} European Parliament|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> * [[Rebecca Harms]], Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Germany and member of the Greens group: "It's important to have this Stratcom, but its interaction with national bodies is not strong enough".<ref name="europarl.europa.eu"/> * Former Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said that: "They provide an excellent instrument. We would of course not be able to do it in other ways".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pov.international/truslen-fra-ost-eller-hvordan-jeg-holdt-op-med-bekymre-mig-og-laerte-elske-sandheden/|title=Truslen fra øst eller: Hvordan jeg holdt op med at bekymre mig og lærte at elske sandheden - POV|last=Skovgaard|first=Morten|date=2017-01-30|work=POV|access-date=2018-03-19|language=da-DK}}</ref> * Former Czech Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]]: "This team is capable of generating quality results".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vlada.cz/cz/media-centrum/aktualne/premier-bohuslav-sobotka-se-zucastnil-stratcom-summitu-2017-156424/|title=Premiér Bohuslav Sobotka se zúčastnil Stratcom Summitu 2017|access-date=2018-03-19|language=cs}}</ref> * Edward Lucas, vice president at [[Center for European Policy Analysis|CEPA]], said that the East StratCom's Disinformation Review is "the best weekly bulletin on Russian propaganda in the West" next after Ukrainian similar project, StopFake, which he considers to be "the gold standard".<ref name="Lecture by Edward Lucas">{{Citation|title=Lecture by Edward Lucas|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sx_cqNR3bJA|language=en|accessdate=2018-03-19}}</ref> * According to The New York Times, East Stratcom serves as "Europe’s front line against this onslaught of fake news".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/20/world/europe/europe-combats-a-new-foe-of-political-stability-fake-news.html|title=Europe Combats a New Foe of Political Stability: Fake News|last=Scott|first=Mark|date=2017-02-20|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-19|last2=Eddy|first2=Melissa|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> * Canadian [[Maclean's|Maclean's Magazine]]: "As for who first noticed that Moscow was gunning for Freeland, that’s something that has yet to show up in any banner Canadian headlines. It was the European Union’s East StratCom Task Force, a unit of the External Action Service (the EU’s foreign ministry and diplomatic branch). The Task Force was set up in March 2015 as a kind of early warning system to detect incoming Kremlin disinformation campaigns".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/how-russias-attack-on-freeland-got-traction-in-canada/|title=How Russia's attack on Freeland got traction in Canada - Macleans.ca|date=2017-03-14|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US}}</ref> * East StratCom Task Force in EU Observer: "Eight member states have urged the EU's foreign service to significantly expand its work on countering Russian propaganda. They said in a letter to EU foreign affairs chief Federica Mogherini that "in the face of unabated third party disinformation campaigns … we see an urgent need to further enhance the EU's StratCom capabilities (…) East StratCom circulates online notes that debunk Russian disinformation and has attracted 30,000 followers to its Twitter account. It also promotes positive coverage of the EU in former Soviet states".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/foreign/139573|title=Mogherini urged to do more on Russian propaganda|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref> More in [[EU Observer]]: "Its Disinformation Review, a weekly newsletter, and its daily tweets and infographics, should be in the laptops and phones of all MEPs and senior EU officials".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://euobserver.com/opinion/136198|title=[Opinion] No joke: Russian propaganda poses EU threat|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref> * Lawfare Blog about the team: "The task force has made some meaningful contributions to the efforts to counter disinformation warfare. Over the course of its operation, East StratCom has identified over 3,500 disinformation cases (…) These statistics highlight the global nature of the problem, and the benefit of having a body working on disinformation beyond a single country’s borders. East StratCom’s supranational view also allows it to provide valuable insights into the broader strategy and goals of pro-Kremlin disinformation operations because it can see them as a cohesive whole, rather than isolated incidents in individual countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lawfareblog.com/european-union-steps-its-fight-against-fake-news|title=The European Union Steps Up its Fight Against Fake News|date=2017-11-14|work=Lawfare|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en}}</ref>
=== Criticism === An article published October 2016 on Kommunikations Forum analyses the sources East StratCom use for debunking alleged disinformation. It criticizes the top three sites, Ukrainian StopFake, EU and NATO, for not being objective credible sources in this regard.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kommunikationsforum.dk/artikler/Hvad-er-EU-s-anti-propaganda-task-forces-ideologiske-fundament|title=EU tilbageviser propaganda med objektiv sandhed|last=|first=|date=26 October 2016|work=Kommunikations Forum|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/29394520/Analysis_of_East_StratCom_sources_for_debunking_pro-Kremlin_misinformation|title=Analysis of East StratCom sources for debunking pro-Kremlin misinformation|last=Jesper|first=Larsen|date=24 October 2016|website=Academia|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
An opinion piece written by Danish commentator, Iben Thranholm, published on Russia Insider October 2015, were listed by East StratCom as pro-Kremlin disinformation. Member of the Danish Parliament, Marie Krarup, upon discovery raised the issue in January 2017, demanding Foreign Minister, Anders Samuelsen, to take action and stop ‘black listing’ of opinions, which he declined as the listing in his view was correctly labeled 'disinformation in support for Russia'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.altinget.dk/eu/artikel/udenrigsminister-dansk-debattoer-er-korrekt-opfoert-paa-propaganda-liste|title=Minister: Dansk debattør er korrekt opført på propaganda-liste|last=|first=|date=12 January 2017|website=Altinget|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref> In response 28 commentators wrote a joint critique stressing their concern that ‘anybody with a critical view on mass immigration could end up in the black book of EU’.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.b.dk/kommentarer/28-kommentatorer-udenrigsministeren-stoetter-sortlistning-af-iben-thranholm|title=28 kommentatorer: Udenrigsministeren støtter sortlistning af Iben Thranholm|last=|first=|date=16 January 2017|website=Berlingske Tidende|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
An article published October 2016 on Folkets Avis, lists several instances, where East StratCom has labelled critique of non Western immigration to EU as pro-Kremlin disinformation, regardless that neither the media or the content has any relation to Russia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.folkets.dk/c/russisk-propaganda-EU-islamkritik|title=EU's East Stratcom: Islamkritik er russisk propaganda|last=|first=|date=6 October 2016|website=Folkets Avis|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref>
Research conducted by investigative journalists at Danish newspaper, Politiken, showed that East StratCom along with Western media falsely blamed separatists, not government forces, in Eastern Ukraine for initiating an offensive in the area of Avdiivka in January 2017. Sources used by East StratCom included [[Inform Napalm|InformNapalm]] which the article shows has ties to Ukrainian death list, [[Myrotvorets]] (Peacemaker) that lists people including journalists as 'traitors' for expressing certain opinions or visiting separatist controlled areas in Eastern Ukraine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://politiken.dk/udland/art5851073/EU-er-fanget-i-propaganda-krigens-t%C3%A5ger|title=EU er fanget i propaganda-krigens tåger|last=|first=|date=27 February 2017|work=Politiken|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Upon discovery of being listed for publishing pro-Kremlin disinformation, three Dutch major media organisations has sued the EU for libel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kvdl.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2018/02/Writ-of-summons-GS-TPO-Gelderlander-EU-Disinfo.pdf|title=Court subpoena in English|last=|first=|date=19 February 2018|website=Kenny Van der Laan lawfirm|access-date=28 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2018/02/dutch-media-outlets-take-eu-to-court-over-disinformation-claims/|title=Dutch media outlets take EU to court over disinformation claims|last=|first=|date=21 February 2018|work=Dutch News|access-date=28 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.poynter.org/news/three-publications-are-suing-eu-over-fake-news-allegations|title=Three publications are suing the EU over fake news allegations|last=|first=|date=28 February 2018|work=Poynter|access-date=1 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On 6 March 2018, a majority of 109 votes to 41 of the Dutch Parliament voted to close EUvsDisinfo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tweedekamer.nl/kamerstukken/moties/detail?id=2018Z03708&did=2018D18080|title=Gewijzigde motie van de leden Kwint en Yesilgöz-Zegerius over het opheffen van EU versus Disinfo (t.v.v. 21501-34-286) (Proposal to close East StratCom)|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|website=Tweede Kamer|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 March 2018}}</ref> On 8 March 2018, East StratCom announced they had deleted the listings of Dutch media in their database "following a detailed review".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://euvsdisinfo.eu/removal-of-three-cases-further-to-complaints-by-dutch-media/|title=Removal of three cases further to complaints by Dutch media|last=|first=|date=8 March 2018|website=EU vs Disinformation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 March 2018}}</ref> On 9 March 2018, Dutch Minister of the Interior, who had previously<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rd.nl/vandaag/politiek/kabinet-trotseert-kamer-over-nepnieuwswaakhond-1.1471637|title=Kabinet trotseert Kamer over nepnieuwswaakhond (Cabinet defies Chamber about fake news watchdog)|last=|first=|date=6 March 2018|work=Reformatorisch Dagblad|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> opposed closing EUvsDisinfo, said that the government would make a case for closing it in the European Union.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nos.nl/artikel/2221353-ook-ollongren-wil-nu-af-van-europese-waakhond-nepnieuws.html|title=Ook Ollongren wil nu af van Europese waakhond nepnieuws (Ollongren now also wants to get rid of European watchdog fake news)|last=|first=|date=10 March 2018|work=NOS|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://politiek.tpo.nl/2018/03/09/ollongren-nu-toch-anti-nepnieuwsbureau/|title=Minister Kajsa Ollongren nu toch tegen anti-nepnieuwsbureau (Minister Kajsa Ollongren now against anti-fake news agency)|last=|first=|date=9 March 2018|work=The Post Online (TPO)|access-date=12 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On 13 March 2018 the three Dutch media withdrew their case.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nos.nl/artikel/2222185-media-trekken-kort-geding-tegen-eu-om-nepnieuws-in.html|title=Media trekken kort geding tegen EU om nepnieuws in|access-date=2018-03-19|language=nl}}</ref>

page.title: Emancipation of the Jews in the United Kingdom
